body.p:
To His Excellency
Thos. E. Bramlette
Govenor of Kentucky
Your Petitioner John Fahay would respectfully state that he was convicted at the May term 1864 of the Jefferson Circuit Court for one year upon a charge of stealing 4 1/2 lbs of Tea.
Your petitioner has a wife & three children who would be entirely helpless in the event of the sentence beeing enforced. Your Excellency is respectfully refered to the signers of this petition.
Your petitioner prays your Excellency to Grant him a pardon

In the absence of J. R. Dupuy, the Commonwealth's Atty, I prosecuted in the above case. Fahy was guilty. It is, I think, his first offence. The property
was restored the day it was taken.
The man has a large family, much needing his daily labor for a support. His wife is almost heart-broken. It is a case for Executive clemency

I am very truly
Yr Friend
J. G. Wilson
I know very little of the case the wife of the dft seems to have three children & I am told is a good woman & has no reliance for a support for her family except upon the labor of her husband
Under all the circumstances I am induced to ask the petitioner's pardon. It may not be a case for Executive clemency, but it is a much better case than that of Brockman or Brown.

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
John Fahay
Pardon granted
Tho E Bramlette
Govr of Ky
Grand Larceny
one year
18th May/64
